statement.text: Phlegmasia represents the spectrum of limb-threatening venous thrombosis: phlegmasia alba dolens (PAD - massive iliofemoral DVT with painful white swelling) progresses to phlegmasia cerulea dolens (PCD - cyanotic, severely swollen leg with impaired arterial inflow due to compartment pressure) and ultimately venous gangrene if untreated.
statement.formal: Phlegmasia Spectrum: Alba Dolens (pale, painful, swollen) → Cerulea Dolens (blue, bullae, arterial compromise) → Venous Gangrene (tissue death)

explanation.intuition: Phlegmasia is like a dam completely blocking a river. In phlegmasia alba dolens, the blockage causes severe backup (massive swelling) but some flow continues (pale). In phlegmasia cerulea dolens, the pressure gets so high that even arterial blood can't get in - the leg turns blue and starts dying. It's venous thrombosis so severe it causes arterial ischemia.
explanation.key_insight: Phlegmasia cerulea dolens is a surgical emergency requiring immediate intervention to save the limb. The progression from alba to cerulea dolens indicates impending venous gangrene with irreversible tissue loss.
explanation.technical_details: PCD involves near-total venous outflow obstruction causing tissue pressure exceeding capillary perfusion pressure, leading to arterial inflow impairment. Compartment syndrome physiology applies. Risk factors: malignancy (50%), HIT, hypercoagulable states, May-Thurner anatomy. Amputation rates without intervention: 20-50%.

phlegmasia_alba_dolens.pathophysiology: Massive iliofemoral DVT with partial venous obstruction
phlegmasia_alba_dolens.arterial_flow: Preserved (peripheral pulses present but may be hard to palpate)
phlegmasia_alba_dolens.urgency: Urgent - may progress to cerulea dolens

phlegmasia_cerulea_dolens.appearance: Cyanotic, tense, bullae formation, severe pain
phlegmasia_cerulea_dolens.pathophysiology: Near-complete venous obstruction → tissue pressure exceeds capillary perfusion

venous_gangrene.pathophysiology: Irreversible tissue death from prolonged ischemia

alba_dolens: Pulses difficult to palpate but present

definitive.catheter_directed_thrombolysis: First-line in stable patients with no contraindications
definitive.pharmacomechanical_thrombectomy: Rapid thrombus removal, preferred in many centers
definitive.surgical_thrombectomy: If endovascular not available or failed

definition.@value: Limb-threatening massive venous thrombosis causing venous outflow obstruction severe enough to impair arterial inflow

clinical_pearls: Alba dolens = pale (arterial flow OK); Cerulea dolens = blue (arterial flow impaired)
50% of patients with phlegmasia have underlying malignancy
Absent pulses in a massively swollen blue leg = PCD, surgical emergency
Don't rely on elevated compartment pressures - clinical diagnosis + rapid intervention

medicalCode.description: Phlebitis and thrombophlebitis of unspecified deep vessels of lower extremities
